raw_text:
Ireland 17-12 South Africa
 
 Ronan O'Gara scored all Ireland's points as the home side claimed only their second ever win over South Africa on an emotional day at Lansdowne Road.
 
 O'Gara's first-half try, poached after a quick tap-penalty, helped the Irish to a 8-3 lead at half-time. Three further O'Gara penalties extended Ireland's lead to 17-6 as the game entered the final quarter. Two Percy Montgomery penalties set up a frantic finish but Ireland held out to claim a famous victory. Ireland began strongly and were never led, but the match was tense and closely fought throughout. Aware of the threat posed by the South Africans, Ireland pressed hard from the outset, and played some impressive rugby while searching for a breakthrough. Early on, Denis Hickie thought he was in for a try after a delightful backline move but Shane Horgan's pass was adjudged to have gone forward by referee Paul Honiss.
 
 Ireland continued to press and they showed their intent by opting for a line-out in the 19th minute when three straight-forward points were on offer. Another South African infringement a minute later led to Ireland's first points - O'Gara took a quick tap-penalty and charged over the opposition line for an Irish try. The Springboks could feel hard done by as captain John Smit had his back to the play when O'Gara pounced after referee Honiss had told the skipper to warn his own players after consistent infringements. Stung by the score, the South Africans almost replied with a try of their own within 60 seconds with Geordan Murphy's ankle-tap tackle denying a certain try for Percy Montgomery. However, the Springboks did win a penalty a minute later which Montgomery easily slotted to cut Ireland's lead to 5-3.
 
 Ireland got out of jail when the South Africans had a three-to-one overlap near the Irish line only to waste the chance. After the sustained Springboks pressure, the Irish produced an attack of their own in the 34th minute which culminated with O'Gara's clever drop-goal to restore his side's lead to five points which remained the margin at half-time. Sustained Irish pressure immediately after half-time was rewarded by another O'Gara penalty. However, Montgomery responded quickly by slotting over a superb penalty from near the right touchline to cut Ireland's lead to five points again. Montgomery then burst through the Irish defence in the 48th minute and it took a superb Girvan Dempsey tackle to prevent a try. The South Africans suffered a double-blow in the 52nd minute when Schalk Burger was sin-binned for the second week in a row after killing the ball and O'Gara punished the transgression by notching another penalty.
 
 In the 61st minute, Hickie was left frustrated by a poor pass from Girvan Dempsey as a chance to seal the match was wasted. However, a late tackle on Brian O'Driscoll enabled O'Gara to notch another penalty in the 63rd minute which extended Ireland's lead to 17-6. However, two Montgomery penalties had Ireland's lead in peril again as the Springboks closed to within five points with seven minutes remaining. South Africa produced a huge effort in the closing minutes but Ireland held on to claim a deserved victory.
 
 G Dempsey; G Murphy, B O'Driscoll (capt), S Horgan, D Hickie; R O'Gara, P Stringer; R Corrigan, S Byrne, J Hayes, M O'Kelly, P O'Connell, S Easterby, J O'Connor, A Foley.
 
 F Sheahan, M Horan, D O'Callaghan, E Miller, G Easterby, D Humphreys, K Maggs.
 
 : P Montgomery; B Paulse, M Joubert, De Wet Barry, A Willemse, J van der Westhuyzen; F Du Preez; O Du Randt, J Smit (captain), E Andrews, B Botha, V Matfield, S Burger, AJ Venter, J van Niekerk.
 
 : H Shimange, CJ van der Linde, G Britz, D Rossouw, M Claassens, J de Villiers, G du Toit/J Fourie.
 
 Paul Honiss (New Zealand)
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland 17-12 South Africa
Ireland scored all points and held on to a second win over South Africa. Ireland's Ronan O'Gara scored two penalties in the first half to give his side an 8-3 lead at halftime. 

In the final quarter, O'Gara added three more penalties but was denied two opportunities to score when captain John Smit was warned and then denied a possible try with ankle-tap tackle on Percy Montgomery. However, after being penalized for another infringement earlier, Smit was awarded five points.

The Springboks were able to close the gap to 5-3 at halftime due in part to their poor penalties. But Ireland continued to press and eventually scored an important drop-goal in the 34th minute to give them a two-point lead with 10 minutes remaining.

Ireland's final score was confirmed when O'Gara added his third penalty of the game, this time sealing a famous victory for Ireland as they defeated South Africa 17-12.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland won 17-12 over South Africa at Lansdowne Road, with Ronan O'Gara scoring all of Ireland's points. The Irish took an early lead and maintained it despite a strong Springboks effort, with Percy Montgomery scoring two penalties for South Africa. A crucial tackle by Girvan Dempsey in the 48th minute helped prevent a try, while O'Gara's penalties kept Ireland ahead until the final minutes.
gemma2:2b: Ireland defeated South Africa 17-12 at Lansdowne Road to win their second ever match against the Springboks. Ronan O'Gara scored all Ireland's points with a try and multiple penalties. Despite a strong start by South Africa, Ireland controlled the game throughout.  The final minutes saw intense pressure from both sides, but Ireland held on for the victory.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ronan O'Gara scored Ireland's only try at Lansdowne Road as they edged out South Africa to claim their second win over the South African home team. The match was intense with a frantic finish and the Springboks playing well, but the Irish were able to hold on to claim a 17-6 victory.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland beat South Africa 17-12 in a closely contested match at Lansdowne Road. O'Gara scored all Ireland's points, including the first try and two subsequent penalties to extend the lead to 17-6. Despite pressure from the Springboks, Ireland held onto their victory.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland defeated South Africa 17-12 at Lansdowne Road with Ronan O’Gara scoring all Ireland’s points. The Irish took an early lead through a first-half try and further penalties, while the Springboks responded with two penalties each by Percy Montgomery. Ireland held off the late South African push to claim victory after sustaining pressure. Key players for Ireland included R. O'Gara (capt), S. Horgan, D. Hickie, P. Stringer; for South Africa, P. Montgomery, B. Paulse, J. van der Westhuizen, and F. Du Preez. Referee was Paul Honiss from New Zealand.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be concise and to the point, focusing on the main ideas and key details of the text. Here's a possible summary:

"Ireland 17-12 South Africa" is a rugby match that took place on November 30, 2019 at Lansdowne Road in Dublin, Ireland. The game was played between the Irish Rugby Football Union (IRFU) and the South African Rugby Football Union (SARFU).

The Irish team, led by captain John Smit, had a strong squad with players such as Brian O'Driscoll, G Dempsey, and B Botha. The Irish defense was well-organized and managed to hold off the Springboks attack from the start of the game. However, South Africa's possession and attacking flair proved too much for the Irish team to handle.

The Irish offense, led by O'Gara, made a series of clever passes and tackles to get the ball back into their own hands. The Irish defense was able to hold on to the ball for several minutes before it was turned over or lost possession.

In the 61st minute, South Africa's defense managed to score two tries against Ireland, but they were quickly countered by a series of Irish tackles and passes. In the 75th minute, South Africa scored a try on a penalty kick from G Dempsey, who was able to get the ball back into their own hands after a poor pass from O'Gara.

The Irish defense held on to the game until the end of the match, but they were ultimately outplayed by South Africa and lost 17-6. The Irish team's performance in this match is considered one of their best in recent years.

<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this Ireland vs. South Africa rugby match. Let me read through the text carefully.

So, Ireland scored 17 points and came out on an emotional day at Lansdowne Road. They had only their second win overall. Their first try was a tap penalty after a backline move by Denis Hickie, giving them an 8-3 lead. Then they scored two more penalties to make it 17-6.

The South Africans were threatening but struggled early on. Paul Honiss gave them a quick response with a try, and then Smit tried to respond but was blocked. The game went back-to-back, which is common in rugby matches.

Ireland kept trying to score, and in the 34th minute, O'Gara made a clever drop-goal to get it back to five points at half-time. Then they had more pressure, and O'Gara scored again with two penalties. However, the South Africans responded by slotting over a penalty near the right touchline and forcing another try.

In the 52nd minute, Schalk Burger was sin-binned for two weeks in a row. That probably gave South Africa a chance to respond. But I don't see any indication of it happening, which could be a big blow for Ireland.

Ireland held onto their lead with Paul Honiss' final tackle in the 63rd minute. They had seven minutes left and still won, claiming a deserved victory. The game was closely fought throughout, and South Africa's captain Smit made a strong impression by scoring early on despite being near the play when O'Gara scored.

In summary, Ireland's key players were O'Gara, Paul Honiss, and maybe some others like Denis Hickie and Shane Horgan. South Africa had Smit, Schalk Burger, and possibly another forward like De Wet Barry or Jefan Venter. The match was intense with both sides pressing their sides hard.

I need to make sure I capture the main points: Ireland won on an emotional day, first half try, second half attempts leading them to 17-6, South Africans had a tough start but fell back, Paul Honiss scoring early in a big threat spot. Also, mention Smit's impact.
</think>

Ireland defeated South Africa on an emotional day at Lansdowne Road, securing their only win overall and proving they were the better team. Ireland scored 17 points, starting strong with O'Gara’s tap penalty after Hickie’s backline move. Paul Honiss provided a quick response from the South Africans, though they eventually fell to 17-6. Ireland’s pressure led them to an 8-3 lead at half-time and then to victory in the final minutes, showcasing their resilience despite a tough challenge.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ireland beat South Africa by a score of 8-3 in a rugby match played at Lansdowne Road stadium on an emotional day in December 1962, with the game ending tied at half-time with both teams down by only two points. Ireland pressed strongly and they displayed impressive rugby while facing a South African threat. In the second half of the match, Ireland scored all their points from a quick tap-penalty for a Frenchman named Ronan O'Gara, but the home side also managed to secure four points through Percy Montgomery's try. The Irish captain John Smit received a yellow card in the 19th minute and another player, Stuing, earned a red card after conceding an early penalty for South Africa infraction. South Africa almost scored a try of their own, but Ireland's captain Stuing saved it with an excellent goal kick. Afterwards, South Africa failed to score again, while Ireland increased their lead by scoring five more points through another O'Gara penalty. The final score was 8-3 in favor of Ireland.

Ronan O'Gara's contributions were pivotal, scoring all Irish points with tries and multiple penalties. Ireland began strongly, capitalizing on a quick tap-penalty try by O'Gara in the 19th minute. Despite South Africa's strong defense and near-tries, Ireland maintained control. Two more O'Gara penalties extended their lead to 17-6 by half-time.
